div.p: I’ve gone through quite a lot of training to get where I am today, really because I really enjoy the vocation I’m in and because I enjoyed it
I knew that if I wanted to get on I really would have to do something about my reading and writing; with my disability dyslexia
it was that sometimes I had to concentrate five times as hard as everybody else and also I had to find different ways of retaining information
and I found the best way for me funnily enough was to do like shorthand-type notes or one word or one sentence which allowed me to go back
and it would actually then refresh my memory. I’ve got National Vocational qualifications in this industry, I’ve got some qualifications to teach
in this industry which I’m really pleased about, you know, and I also can actually go out there and actually be an NVQ Assessor
as well as an NVQ Invigilator so I’ve got quite a lot of qualifications and I think I’ve got more qualifications in the 18 years
when I was working in London than I have let’s say in the whole time I was at school. Now I know it’s an 18 year life experience
at work but the qualifications I’ve got I think have really stood me in good stead.
